title.rendered: Call for Speakers is now Open!

content.rendered:
The WordCamp Asia 2024 Call for Speakers is officially open!

This is an incredible opportunity for you to share your knowledge, experience, and passion with the vibrant WordPress community in Asia. Whether you are a seasoned speaker or considering taking the stage for the first time at a flagship event, we encourage you to give it a try and be a part of the largest WordPress conference in Asia.

Apply Now

To keep our event dynamic and engaging, we are planning to run at least 4 different styles of sessions. Pick one that suits your topic best and apply!

  • Long Talks
  • Lightning Talks
  • Panel Disscussions
  • Workshops

For those looking to make the greatest impact, look no further: the venue boasts of a plenary hall that can host up to 3000 attendees. We encourage speakers from all backgrounds, regardless of gender, ethnicity, age, or experience level, to participate and enrich the event with their unique voices.

We’re a small team and would like to be spending our time creating more value. To help us, we’d love for everyone to submit a maximum of 2 topics – if you do submit more, we’d only consider the 2 latest entries. For more details about the Call for Speakers, please take a look at the dedicated page we have created.

Call for Speakers

Submit your speaker proposals now and join us at WordCamp Asia 2024!

Let’s come together to celebrate the open-source spirit, learn from each other, and make WordCamp Asia 2024 a great one. The deadline for speaker submissions is September 30 23:00 Taipei, Taiwan time (UTC+8), so don’t miss it!

We can’t wait to see the incredible ideas you have in store for us. Let’s make WordCamp Asia 2024 a resounding success, together!

title.rendered: WordCamp Asia 2024 in Taiwan is now officially set!¬†

content.rendered:
WordCamp Asia 2024 in Taiwan is now officially set! 

üìÖ Save the Date: March 7, 8 , 9, 2024 

üìç Venue: Taipei International Convention Center (TICC), Taiwan 

We are thrilled to announce that we have secured the Taipei International Convention Center (TICC), a remarkable 5-story building exclusively rented for 3 days, as the venue for our event. 

This prestigious venue is located in Taipei’s commercial and financial hub, just a 3-minute walk from Taipei 101, the iconic landmark of Taiwan. With a main hall capacity of over 3000 people, it provides ample space for our attendees. The conference rooms will feature 3-5 tracks, ensuring a diverse range of sessions, and the venue also offers spacious common areas, perfect for rest and networking.

Get ready to be amazed as TICC goes above and beyond expectations, delivering a truly unforgettable experience. 

__ 

WordCamp Asia 2024 is gearing up to be an event with a vibrant atmosphere, diverse community, and mind-blowing sharings. We welcome everyone, whether you‚Äôre a seasoned WordPress pro or just stepping into the magical world of blogging. 

Stay tuned for more updates. We’re dedicated to offering you an unforgettable experience. Get ready for the most epic gathering of WordPress lovers at WordCamp Asia 2024 in the heart of Taiwan! 

#WCAsia2024

#WCAsia

#WordCampAsia

title.rendered: Preparations have started for WordCamp Asia 2024

content.rendered:
Hello!

It‚Äôs been awhile since we were in touch and we hope a good number of you are enjoying your time at our sister event, WordCamp Europe!

It‚Äôs been an interesting few weeks with the formation of the organising team and working through the venue contract.

Andy, Devin, Eric, Yuli, and I spent time with the local team visiting the venue and consulting with production companies that would help us set WordCamp Asia apart from anything you‚Äôve seen.

We‚Äôre just about to sign the venue. You can now update your calendars for WordCamp Asia to happen early March 2024 (confirmed dates to be shared in a week or so!). Here‚Äôs a quick sneak preview of the location – we‚Äôre renting out a building (almost!)

More details to come very soon.

The local community is massive and I‚Äôve been told that WordCamp Taiwan (this October) alone would boast of at least 500 attendees. While we were on the same trip, we were lucky to be able to celebrate  the 20th Anniversary of WordPress with the Taiwanese community.  

There‚Äôs also active work bringing in government support and other open source communities across the region (e.g. Hong Kong) to WordCamp Asia next year.

Look forward to our announcement in the coming 1 or 2 weeks for both the venue announcement and event dates!

title.rendered: Behind the Lineup: Ryan Welcher

content.rendered:
As we countdown to WordCamp Asia 2024, each week we‚Äôre inviting you to go behind the lineup and get to know the folks who will be taking to the stage. In today‚Äôs post, we chat with Ryan Welcher, a Developer Advocate sponsored by Automattic, specializes in Gutenberg and WordPress, contributes regularly, and streams about custom block development on RyanWelcherCodes on Twitch.

Q. Firstly, welcome to the lineup! We‚Äôre so glad to have you here. Can you start by telling us a bit about yourself? Where will you be joining the event from, and what does your day-to-day look like?

I am coming from Ontario Canada and it will be my first time in Taipei. As a developer advocate, my day to day can run from live streaming, to creating coding demos, to hosting Developer Hours, to interacting with the community on social media and platforms.

Q. We‚Äôre lucky to be welcoming a diverse range of speakers to our program in 2024. What interested you to apply to WordCamp Asia as a speaker?

I love going to WordCamps and meeting developers every chance I get! I am also very passionate about helping developers learn and applying to speak checks both of those boxes for me.

Q. What can audiences expect to learn from your talk/s? Are there any advance sneak peeks or knowledge bombs you can offer us?

I hope that attendees of my workshop will come away with tangible items that can be applied to their every day projects.

Q. What are you most looking forward to at WordCamp Asia 2024? Is there someone you‚Äôre looking forward to rubbing shoulder with, or a local delicacy you‚Äôd like to sample? 

I am very excited to see all of WordPress community friends again and to hopefully make some new ones.

Q. Lightning Round! 

Most-visited website: WordPress Developer Blog.

Most-have gadget: AirPods.

Go-to podcast: Gutenberg Changelog.

Find out more about Ryan’s appearance at WordCamp Asia 2024¬†here.

title.rendered: Get Ready for the Contributor Day

content.rendered:
WordCamp Asia 2024 Contributor Day is getting closer! Together, we‚Äôll contribute, network, and learn! How exciting!

The WordCamp Asia team has worked tirelessly to create a welcoming event, to ensure both new and experienced contributors have a great time working together to improve WordPress.

Especially for new contributors, we have an Orientation Workshop and Human Library for the first time on any Contributor Day. Even if you are new, we have a lot of things to offer. Don‚Äôt panic, get attended! 

We‚Äôll start our registration process from 9:00 AM local time. Ensure you bring your WordCamp Asia ticket and Contributor Day registration confirmation email. 

To be a part of the Contributor Day, you’ll need WordPress.org account. Please create an account if you don’t have already. Also, having WordPress slack account is added advantage.

Altogether, we have 13 different teams, and every team has plans for the day. They will also be informed during the opening ceremony. But, you might want to prepare for which team you want to join. Read the plans of each team below.¬†

Accessibility

The Accessibility team welcomes everyone interested in contributing to the Accessibility of WordPress core and resources.

During the time together, they’ll cover the basics of what the team does, and how to get involved as a contributor to our various working groups, review active tickets at weekly bug scrubs, attend bi-weekly meetings, and get help during office hours.

If you’re new to Contributor Day, they’ll cover some basic accessibility education with some examples of poor vs. good accessibility. For attendees with development experience, you are welcome to review active tickets or perform testing for accessibility.

To contribute to this team, they ask that you ( if you haven’t already):

  • Create a WordPress.org account.
  • Set up a GitHub.com account. ( if you haven’t already):
  • Joining the Accessibility team on the Making WordPress Slack channel

Community 

The WordPress Community Team provides support for everything related to organizing WordPress events! During WC Asia, visit the Community Team table to ask questions about organizing WordPress events (meetups, WordCamps, and other events); submit a meetup, WordCamp, or event organizer application; participate in an in-person organizer orientation and/or budget review; or receive training on the role of Community Team Supporter.

Everyone is welcome, especially meetup organizers or prospective organizers, and others who want to organize WordPress events in their local community.

Meetups (with Roc√≠o Valdivia)

  • Questions related to starting or reactivating a new WordPress Meetup group in your city, participate in an in-person orientation and other Q&A related to WordPress Meetups.

WordCamps (with Sam Suresh)

  • Questions related to organizing WordCamps in your city, planning details, eligibility and other WordCamp questions.

Other WordPress Events [formerly called ‚ÄòNextGen‚Äô] (with Julia Golomb)

  • Learn how to host creative event formats, and how to apply and get started.

Community Team Supporters (with Devin Maeztri)

  • Get to know how you can join and contribute to the WordPress Community Team as a Supporter.

You can also check Community team page and know more about the team before joining the table.

Core 

Whether you‚Äôre joining Contributor Day in person in Taipei or following along online via the #contributor-day Slack channel, thank you and welcome!

To start with, at a minimum, you‚Äôll need to have the latest stable version of nodejs and npm, which you can find here: https://nodejs.org/en (LTS is the one Core and Gutenberg use) and Git installed locally (for core you can also use SVN).

Depending on whether you‚Äôre planning to work on Core or Gutenberg, there are a few different options:

For Core, clone the repo and follow the instructions here to install the included development environment. Docker is a prerequisite for it, so if you pick this option, go ahead and install Docker first.

For the editor, clone the Gutenberg repo and you can then use the wp-env package, which also requires Docker.

An alternative to these is wp-now, which is a more lightweight option that requires only node/npm. It‚Äôs based on wp-playground. Note that there have been issues with Playground on Windows.

For those attending in person, we‚Äôll be located in the Code Lounge (South Lounge) on the third floor.

It‚Äôs also required to create a WordPress.org account if you don‚Äôt already have one, and if you‚Äôre using Git, you‚Äôll also need a GitHub.com account.

Documentation

The Documentation Team is responsible for keeping WordPress documentation accurate and up-to-date. During WordCamp Asia Contributors Day, they‚Äôll be reviewing and updating existing content.

Whether you’re a developer or a regular WordPress user, you can join the table and contribute to the project! They have several projects to work on: developer documentation will suit you if you have technical and coding knowledge, and the end-user documentation project is perfect if you‚Äôre an avid user and want to create a better guide for fellow WordPressers

No prior experience is necessary! They‚Äôll provide guidance and support to help you get started. All you have to prepare are WordPress.org and GitHub accounts.

You can also check getting started at a contributor day page for more information. 

Marketing

The Marketing team helps promote WordPress to current and future users and contributors. They create and amplify campaigns to support the growth of the WordPress project.

If you‚Äôre passionate about taking part in campaigns and initiatives intended to help spread the word about WordPress ‚Äî both internally and externally ‚Äî then this is the team for you!

Some of the things you can get involved in include social media initiatives, content creation, and helping onboard new contributors to the WordPress community.

In order to get started with the Marketing Team during Contributor Day, you‚Äôll need to have a WordPress.org account and GitHub.com account. We also regularly communicate on the Make WordPress channel on Slack. We‚Äôll help you set those up at the beginning of the sessions, but it would be great if you had that set up already. 

Meta

Meta team would like to work on local development environments for as many Meta projects as possible. Currently, they’ve migrated some to wp-env and will continue with this. But they will also try to get wp-now working for some simple projects.

A second topic is the WPTV redesign. And they will also coordinate with the other team for this. 

You should have WordPress.org account to get started. 

Patterns

On the Patterns table, attendees can expect a more creative direction on how to make beautifully designed, ready-to-go layouts.  Whether you are a seasoned web designer or just starting your journey with Gutenberg, this table is to guide and support you every step of the way. Their work will focus on ideating, working on the basics, and being creative! If you are passionate about being a part of the Patterns team, this is the perfect opportunity for you to join them and contribute to the WordPress community.

During their session, they will also cover the essentials of creating patterns that adhere to the WordPress.org pattern guidelines. Whether you aspire how to create your own pixel-perfect layouts or submit them to the WordPress Patterns directory, they will walk you through the process and share valuable insights. By the end of their gathering, you’ll have all the resources needed to become a WordPress Patterns author in no time!

Furthermore, the Patterns table will be set up at Code Lounge (South Lounge) on the third floor, and they can’t wait to welcome you all to an enriching learning experience. To ensure a smooth and productive session, they kindly request that you create a WordPress.org account. This will help streamline the process and allow you to make the most of your time with us. They are thrilled to have you as part of our community and look forward to an engaging and interactive day at Our Patterns table.

Photos

The Photo Directory team moderates every photo submitted to the WordPress Photo Directory, maintains and improves the directory site itself, and provides resources and documentation to educate, encourage, and facilitate photo contributors.

You can find the Photos Team in the #photos channel in Slack.


Photos Team Resources

  • Photos Team Handbook

Photos Team Projects for Contributor Day

  • Getting folks set up to contribute to the directory and understand the guidelines.
  • Discussion on what makes a good photo, what the moderators look for in moderation, and what makes a good photo description.
  • Any moderators present will moderate as many photos as possible in real-time.

Plugins

To ensure a smooth experience on the day, the Plugins team recommends installing a local development environment on your laptop in advance. The conference venue’s Wi-Fi may only sometimes be optimal, especially when many people are using it simultaneously. Achieving this prerequisite over a stable and fast connection is much simpler.

Here’s the checklist:

  • Latest Local WordPress Setup: You can use tools like MAMP, XAMPP, Local by Flywheel, Docker, or WP-Now.
  • Latest Stable Version of Node.js and npm: You can find it here: https://nodejs.org/en (the LTS version is the one used by Core and Gutenberg).
  • Code Editor: Consider using VS Code or Sublime.
  • Git: it’s optional but good to have.

The Plugins team eagerly anticipates your presence at the event!

Polyglots

The Polyglots team is responsible for ensuring WordPress is available in dozens of languages and many more regions. The Polyglots team consists of volunteers worldwide who help bring WordPress to local communities by providing translations for more than 162 languages.

This theme is excited to welcome you to the Polyglots table. New and existing contributors are welcome, they will be guiding new contributors on translating WordPress projects, translating WordPress core projects,testing out the Translation Events Feature for the very first time.

In preparation, they encourage you to kindly,

  • Create a WordPress.org account.
  • Join the Polyglots channel on Slack.

Support

At the WordPress Support Contributor Table, attendees can expect a comprehensive learning experience covering various aspects of WordPress support. They will gain insights into the essence of genuine support, understanding WordPress.org support guidelines, and handling themes, plugins, and other support issues. 

The table will guide filtering questions based on expertise, creating new support tickets, and successfully resolving issues. Participants will be encouraged to create a WordPress.org account if they haven’t already, emphasizing the free access to a vibrant community, forums, and collaborative opportunities within the WordPress ecosystem.

Themes

The themes team will focus more on Community Themes development. If you are passionate about developing block themes and being a part of the Community Themes project, they love to have you on the themes table.

They will also discuss the WordPress.org theme guidelines. If you want to create themes and submit them in the WordPress themes directory, they will guide you through the process. Join the themes table and be a WordPress theme author in a single day.

The Theme table will be Code Lounge (South Lounge) on the third floor and we will be there to welcome you all.

They request you all to create a WordPress.org account and GitHub.com account. (if you don’t have already).

Training 

The WordPress Training Team helps people learn to use, extend, and contribute to WordPress through learn.wordpress.org.

We’re thrilled to welcome you to the Training Team table at WCAsia Contributor Day. Kindly take a moment to review the Training Team’s plan for the day outlined in the WordCamp Asia 2024 Contributor Day post.

In summary, our main tasks will include writing scripts, reviewing content, translating, vetting topics, and triaging developer issues.

Please come prepared by ensuring you’ve created a WordPress.Org account, joined the Training Team Slack channel, and set up a GitHub account. Instructions for getting ready in advance can be found here: Welcome to the Training Team! If you are a developer, check out these Dev-squad guidelines.

See you soon!

title.rendered: Behind the Lineup: Joe A Simpson Jr

content.rendered:
As we countdown to WordCamp Asia 2024, each week we‚Äôre inviting you to go behind the lineup and get to know the folks who will be taking to the stage. In today‚Äôs post, we chat with Joe A Simpson Jr, the co-founder of BlackPress, is known for his WordCamp contributions and dedication to WordPress accessibility and community growth.

Q. Firstly, welcome to the lineup! We‚Äôre so glad to have you here. Can you start by telling us a bit about yourself? Where will you be joining the event from, and what does your day-to-day look like?

I’m traveling to Taipei from the west coast of the United States. I live in a town in the northern part of LA County named Castaic, CA. I manage our WordPress network for the 3rd largest transit agency in the US, Metro Los Angeles.

Q. We‚Äôre lucky to be welcoming a diverse range of speakers to our program in 2024. What interested you to apply to WordCamp Asia as a speaker?

I live in Los Angeles and I’m drawn to the region by work relationships with colleagues whose parents are from Taiwan, an intern of mine traveled frequently to Taiwan, so it felt natural. I’m a ‘foodie (adventurous eater) and I can’t be more excited to experience a flagship WordPress event abroad and the foods I’ve tried variations of here in LA. First time to the Far East as well!

Q. What can audiences expect to learn from your talk/s? Are there any advance sneak peeks or knowledge bombs you can offer us?

My presentations are always engaging and interactive – I encourage sharing and participating to provide takeaways that the audiences carry back to their local events and projects. Accessibility is a common topic but this topic is probably not discussed as often as it should be. My hope is that they’ll be a paradigm shift about accessibility, but also learn why as a community it should be a foundation of all we do.

Q. What are you most looking forward to at WordCamp Asia 2024? Is there someone you‚Äôre looking forward to rubbing shoulder with, or a local delicacy you‚Äôd like to sample? 

During the pandemic and the virtual WordCamp years, I met, worked alongside, and go to know Ahmed Chaion across thousands of miles. I can’t wait to see him and thank him for being such an incredible contributor and someone I consider a friend.

A colleague I worked with for 7 years said I should try her favorite, stinky tofu, but will probably enjoy mango rice a bit more! I’m loading up on food videos and ALWAYS ask friends and colleagues to share their favorite foods with me!

Engaging with the WordPress Community in general is always exciting!

Q. Tell us something about yourself that we might not know. Party tricks? Secret hobbies?

I’m an illustrator/animator and won a state film festival in high school.

An accomplished home cook and scratch cook – great stress reliever and something friends and family appreciate.

Q. Lightning Round! 

Most-visited website: Foodnetwork.com (I’m a scratch cook).

Most-have gadget: Hiking shoes and a hillside.

Most-read book: The Color of Law Richard Rothstein.

Go-to podcast: The Sporkful, Kitchen Sink WordPress, or The Moth.

Find out more about Joe’s appearance at WordCamp Asia 2024¬†here.

title.rendered: Behind the Lineup: Maestro Stevens

content.rendered:
As we countdown to WordCamp Asia 2024, each week we‚Äôre inviting you to go behind the lineup and get to know the folks who will be taking to the stage. In today‚Äôs post, we chat with Maestro Stevens, the founder of The Iconic Expressions creative agency and a highly skilled brand webmaster known for his innovative WordPress templates.

Q. Firstly, welcome to the lineup! We‚Äôre so glad to have you here. Can you start by telling us a bit about yourself? Where will you be joining the event from, and what does your day-to-day look like?

I’m a brand webmaster, international speaker and founder of a new startup called Iconic Templates‚Ñ¢. I’ll be coming from Akron, Ohio home of LeBron James. During a typical day i’m managing company staff, learning new strategies and trends, and engaging in new business opportunities.

Q. We‚Äôre lucky to be welcoming a diverse range of speakers to our program in 2024. What interested you to apply to WordCamp Asia as a speaker?

I like teaching on topics that I’ve mastered or I’m still experimenting with. WordCamps are typically a great way to teach and learn from the audience at the same time. I also like to travel and haven’t seen Asia yet.

Q. What can audiences expect to learn from your talk/s? Are there any advance sneak peeks or knowledge bombs you can offer us?

Attendees and viewers can expect a different perspective on accessbility and inclusivity in the WordPress ecosystem specifically tied to BIPOC communities.

Q. What are you most looking forward to at WordCamp Asia 2024? Is there someone you‚Äôre looking forward to rubbing shoulder with, or a local delicacy you‚Äôd like to sample? 

I’m excited to explore Taipei and enjoy the people, food and sites.

Q. Tell us something about yourself that we might not know. Party tricks? Secret hobbies?

I like to dance, create music and listen to High-Res music as a private hobby. In another life I was a world-renowned chef but in this life i’m a very good cook.

Q. Lightning Round! 

Most-visited website: Gmail.

Most-have gadget: Macbook Pro.

Most-read book: Never Split The Difference.

Go-to podcast: The Futur.

Find out more about Maestro’s appearance at WordCamp Asia 2024¬†here.

title.rendered: Announcing Our Seventh Invited Speaker: Ben Thompson

content.rendered:
We are excited to welcome Ben Thompson as our next invited speaker for WordCamp Asia 2024. Ben is the founder and author of Stratechery, and pioneered the subscription business model for individual writers.

About Ben Thompson

Ben has been publishing Stratechery on WordPress since 2013. Stratechery is a blog about technology and strategy, and the impact of the Internet on media. That includes blogging: Ben has, from the beginning, been a strong proponent of the idea that not only is blogging not dead but that its future is brighter than ever. That belief was undergirded by the possibility of new business models, particularly subscriptions. Ben proved that with Stratechery, one of the first subscription-supported blogs that created the model for the entire industry. Today Stratechery is a multi-million dollar content business, and Ben is an influential voice in Silicon Valley, Wall Street, and Washington D.C.

Stratechery has, from the beginning, been built on WordPress. WordPress and its ecosystem made it possible for Ben to build a new kind of media company, where he was the only employee. Over the last few years, though, Ben has been working to build what he sees as a missing piece of that ecosystem: software that lets creators truly have a direct connection with their customers.

Session Details

Ben‚Äôs session will tell the story of Stratechery and the development of creator-centric businesses, and how WordPress made that possible. Ben will also introduce Passport, the WordPress plugin that powers Stratechery, and why it can unlock new use cases and business models for creators of all types.

Stay Tuned for more information

We will be delivering more information about our event details and full depth of the schedule. Keep an eye on our blog and social media channels for the latest updates on WordCamp Asia 2024. 

Get Your Tickets Now

title.rendered: Thanks to Xingang Mountain Sponsor ‚Äì Sucuri

content.rendered:

As we eagerly anticipate WordCamp Asia 2024 (March 7-9) at the Taipei International Convention Center (TICC), Sucuri plays a pivotal role in shaping an extraordinary experience for all WordPress users who play a vital role in shaping, safeguarding, and advancing the vibrant WordPress community.

Sucuri, renowned for its expertise in website security, stands as a beacon in fortifying the WordPress community against online threats. Their sponsorship exemplifies a dedication to safeguarding websites, actively contributing to the overall security and resilience of the WordPress ecosystem. By empowering website designers, developers, and owners alike with cutting-edge security solutions, Sucuri not only reflects a commitment to excellence but also actively shapes a future where WordPress sites thrive securely.

Join us at TICC for WordCamp Asia 2024 ‚Äì where collaboration, innovation, and community converge for an unforgettable experience, thanks to the valuable support of Sucuri!

  • One of the most important aspects of your website is security. Whether you‚Äôre an individual blogger or running an enterprise-level application, security should always be a top priority in your website plan. Sucuri gives website owners peace of mind with solutions that prevent hackers from abusing websites and professional response services to those compromised. Sucuri is dedicated to researching the latest and emerging threats affecting websites like yours.

    From security monitoring to malware scanning, detection, and cleanup, Sucuri has the services you need to keep your WordPress-powered website safe and secure. Be sure to stop by the Sucuri booth to meet the team and learn how they can help keep your website Sucuri safe.

    Learn more about Sucuri.

title.rendered: Behind the Lineup: Rich Tabor

content.rendered:
As we countdown to WordCamp Asia 2024, each week we‚Äôre inviting you to go behind the lineup and get to know the folks who will be taking to the stage. In today‚Äôs post, we chat with Rich Tabor, a product manager at Automattic who’s dedicated to enhancing WordPress, aiming to make publishing more user-friendly and centered around human interaction.

Q. Firstly, welcome to the lineup! We‚Äôre so glad to have you here. Can you start by telling us a bit about yourself? Where will you be joining the event from, and what does your day-to-day look like?

I‚Äôm a multidisciplinary maker, specializing in the intersection of product, design and engineering. Sure, it sounds fancy‚Äîbut I really just like to build nice things. I‚Äôm from Atlanta, Georgia, near the east coast of the United States.

Day to day I‚Äôm in my office navigating the various efforts for the next WordPress releases, pushing to make WordPress more intuitive and empowering as ever. You‚Äôll find me sharing knowledge on my blog, https://rich.blog, and on X, designing in the WordPress Design Figma library, and all around the Gutenberg Github repository.

Q. We‚Äôre lucky to be welcoming a diverse range of speakers to our program in 2024. What interested you to apply to WordCamp Asia as a speaker?

Sharing knowledge is an important facet of who I am. I want to impart the art of design thinking to others, continuously raising the bar across the board‚Äîperhaps even making our sphere a bit more intuitive place to be.

Q. What can audiences expect to learn from your talk/s? Are there any advance sneak peeks or knowledge bombs you can offer us?

We‚Äôll dive into the nuances of good, purposeful design, distilling how to leverage design thinking to create intentional experiences for people. It’s not just for designers, but thinkers and tinkerers who like to create.

Q. What are you most looking forward to at WordCamp Asia 2024? Is there someone you‚Äôre looking forward to rubbing shoulder with, or a local delicacy you‚Äôd like to sample? 

This is my first WordCamp Asia! I‚Äôm just as excited to visit such a beautiful country, as I am at engaging with the WordPress community in Asia. And I‚Äôm open to trying most foods; just need a few local friends so take me to the best places!

Q. Tell us something about yourself that we might not know. Party tricks? Secret hobbies?

I‚Äôm a decent electric guitar player, playing with a local band here and there. I‚Äôm known as a Monopoly fiend (the board game). My partner would say I‚Äôm an unusually good guesser.

Q. Lightning Round! 

Most-visited website: Aside from my own site rich.blog, I engage with ChatGPT daily. I can do and learn almost anything, anywhere, from my phone.

Most-read book: I‚Äôve probably read the Harry Potter series the most; it‚Äôs been a few years, but I‚Äôm a big fan.

Go-to podcast: I‚Äôve been enjoying How to Take Over the World by Ben Wilson; it’s full of insightful takes on humans that have taken the world by storm in their time.

title.rendered: Behind the Lineup: Hannah Swain L√∏vik

content.rendered:
As we countdown to WordCamp Asia 2024, each week we‚Äôre inviting you to go behind the lineup and get to know the folks who will be taking to the stage. In today‚Äôs post, we chat with Hannah Swain L√∏vik, senior manager at Automattic responsible for people management within WooCommerce and Happiness Engineering.

Q. Firstly, welcome to the lineup! We‚Äôre so glad to have you here. Can you start by telling us a bit about yourself? Where will you be joining the event from, and what does your day-to-day look like?

I’m excited to be traveling from Stockholm, Sweden to visit WordCamp Asia!

These days, I lead teams of Happiness Engineers supporting WooCommerce at Automattic. I spend large chunks of my time talking to people: how are you doing? What’s working? What’s not working? Part of that is so that I can support them personally, while some of that is so that I can help them better support our products and our merchants. I work across Automattic Happiness to smooth the way for our Happiness Engineers, for example around communication, expectations, recognition, etc.

I still carve out time to focus on my own projects and interests – I’m always looking for ways to be more efficient, to better understand and set priorities, and how to balance work and life. That’s particularly tricky in the Open Source world as it often feels like work and life blend together.

Q. We‚Äôre lucky to be welcoming a diverse range of speakers to our program in 2024. What interested you to apply to WordCamp Asia as a speaker?

I want to speak at WordCamp Asia to connect with a different part of the community. Pressure to perform is high across the world, but particularly high in Asia – I hope that my session on moving from FOMO (the fear of missing out) to JOMO (the joy of missing out) plants some seeds that help people.

Q. What can audiences expect to learn from your talk/s? Are there any advance sneak peeks or knowledge bombs you can offer us?

The idea for this session sparked from a random comment during a conversation. I thought it was neat and wanted to build on it, so fleshed it out and submitted it to WordCamp Asia in September. Now that I’ve been looking for them, it’s surprising just how much material there is around the concept of JOMO (the joy of missing out) – simply being aware that a different approach is possible has helped me find so much inspiration.

For example, did you know that if you live to be 80 years old, you will have lived for about 4000 weeks? What will you have done – or not done? – with that time?

Q. What are you most looking forward to at WordCamp Asia 2024? Is there someone you‚Äôre looking forward to rubbing shoulder with, or a local delicacy you‚Äôd like to sample? 

The people! I have so many amazing people to meet that I haven’t gotten the opportunity to connect with in person before.

I am also deeply curious about the food. Iron eggs?! Bring it on! I’d also love to try a night market.

Q. Tell us something about yourself that we might not know. Party tricks? Secret hobbies?

I’ve recently discovered graphic novels – Saga is amazing, and I can also highly recommend series like Descender.

Bonus edition: I love hats! I have a whole collection. Which one will I be wearing at WC Asia?

Q. Lightning Round! 

Most-visited website: self-hosted RSS instance

Must-have gadget: Onyx Boox Page (ereader)

Most-read book: can’t choose just one, but recently enjoyed Hero Forged by Josh Erikson

Go-to podcast: I struggle to focus on podcasts

Find out more about Hannah’s appearance at WordCamp Asia 2024 here.

content.rendered:
As we countdown to WordCamp Asia 2024, each week we‚Äôre inviting you to go behind the lineup and get to know the folks who will be taking to the stage. In today‚Äôs post, we chat with Gerlynnia Aprille Galgo, a brand strategist, content creator for designers, and digital marketer. She is also the founder of GO Creatives, an independent creative studio that specializes in Branding, Brand Experiences, and Digital Marketing

Q. Firstly, welcome to the lineup! We‚Äôre so glad to have you here. Can you start by telling us a bit about yourself? Where will you be joining the event from, and what does your day-to-day look like?

My name is Gerlynnia Galgo, a Brand Strategist and Designer from the Philippines. I have been assisting Food and Beauty Businesses in thriving within the digital space through Branding and Creative Ads. On the flip side, I am also a Visual Artist and a multi-passionate individual juggling various hobbies. For the majority of my day, I dedicate my time to my freelancing business, play with my dogs, and occasionally, when preparing for an upcoming exhibit, I focus on creating artworks.

Q. We‚Äôre lucky to be welcoming a diverse range of speakers to our program in 2024. What interested you to apply to WordCamp Asia as a speaker?

It has always been a dream to speak internationally. In addition to that, I had a good experience speaking at a local WordCamp last year, where I made friends and connections. Moreover, I want to expand my knowledge and be exposed to an environment where I can learn from people with expertise ranging from tech to marketing.

Q. What can audiences expect to learn from your talk/s? Are there any advance sneak peeks or knowledge bombs you can offer us?

Oooh! I am going to talk about Personal Branding in the AI Era and share tips on how you can work on your personal brand as well.

Q. What are you most looking forward to at WordCamp Asia 2024? Is there someone you‚Äôre looking forward to rubbing shoulder with, or a local delicacy you‚Äôd like to sample? 

I am actually a novice in this industry, so I am looking forward to rubbing shoulders with all the speakers and representing the Philippines. As for local delicacies, it would be nice to try Taiwan‚Äôs Boba and the famous Pounded Chicken!

Q. Tell us something about yourself that we might not know. Party tricks? Secret hobbies?

Secret hobbies? I am trying to complete 366 days of running, as of writing this, I am on Day 16 haha

Q. Lightning Round! 

Most-visited website: Pinterest and Instagram‚Ä®,

Must-have gadget: My laptop and phone‚Ä®

Most-read book: Atomic Habits and Secrets of a Millionaire Mind‚Ä®,

Go-to podcast: Rob Dial and Mel Robbins

    The LiteSpeed Cache plugin can further communicate with QUIC.cloud CDN to serve a site’s content – while honoring the same caching and purging rules – at the CDN edge.LSCache gets its power from LiteSpeed Web Server’s cache engine, which is built into the server core.

    Serve WordPress and WooCommerce accurately, and lightning fast, for both logged-in and guest users, without invoking PHP. Then take it to a global audience with QUIC.cloud CDN.

    Make LiteSpeed Web Server + the LiteSpeed Cache Plugin for WordPress + QUIC.cloud CDN your all-in-one site acceleration platform today!

  • WP Fusion‚Äî the ultimate tool to transform your WordPress site into a fully integrated marketing platform.

    This powerful plugin integrates your site bidirectionally with your CRM or marketing automation platform, unlocking personalized user experiences and streamlined data management. With WP Fusion, you can track user interactions, customize content based on customer profiles, and trigger enrollments, discounts, popups, and more using timers and logic in your connected CRM.

    Its user-friendly interface makes syncing data a breeze, ensuring your CRM is always up to date with the latest data from WordPress. Ideal for businesses aiming to boost their online impact, WP Fusion is more than a plugin‚Äîit’s a gateway to digital mastery.

title.rendered: Behind the Lineup: Mina Tamang

content.rendered:
As we countdown to WordCamp Asia 2024, each week we‚Äôre inviting you to go behind the lineup and get to know the folks who will be taking to the stage. In today‚Äôs post, we chat with Mina Tamang, SEO analyst at CodeWing Solutions.

Q. Firstly, welcome to the lineup! We‚Äôre so glad to have you here. Can you start by telling us a bit about yourself? Where will you be joining the event from, and what does your day-to-day look like?

Namaste from the land of the Himalayas! I will be joining the event all the way from Nepal, where my days are a whirlwind of SEO strategies and crafting captivating content with my amazing team (we’re a bunch of energetic bubbles, trust me!).

But beyond the spreadsheets and algorithms, there’s another side to me. You’ll find me honing my voice at Founders Toastmasters (current VPE, no big deal), always striving to connect and inspire. And in between the hustle, I cherish simple joys, big or small, whether it’s a shared cup of chai with loved ones or exploring a hidden waterfall.

Q. We‚Äôre lucky to be welcoming a diverse range of speakers to our program in 2024. What interested you to apply to WordCamp Asia as a speaker?

My local WordCamp team from Nepal and my boss initially encouraged me to apply for the Speaker role at WordCamp Asia. But the moment I attended my first WordCamp event, I knew I wanted to be on a larger stage. The combined efforts of my team and my own burning desire led me to pursue this opportunity as a speaker at WordCamp Asia.

Q. What can audiences expect to learn from your talk/s? Are there any advance sneak peeks or knowledge bombs you can offer us?

I’m a bit of a storyteller, even when I don’t try! So, I will be sharing SEO tales, filled with real-life struggles and triumphs. But beyond the stories, I want to bust some myths about SEO that plague many business owners. Let’s clear the air and reveal what actually works in the ever-evolving digital world.

Q. What are you most looking forward to at WordCamp Asia 2024? Is there someone you‚Äôre looking forward to rubbing shoulder with, or a local delicacy you‚Äôd like to sample? 

Well, as a first-time flagship WordCamp Asia attendee, I’m wide-eyed and ready to soak it all in: the electrifying talks and workshops, the buzzing energy of the community, and everything else this amazing event has to offer! Taipei itself is a mystery waiting to be explored, and I’m game for anything ‚Äì from local delicacies that’ll tantalize my taste buds to impromptu adventures with fellow WordCampers. Basically, I’m here to learn, connect, and maybe even stumble upon a life-changing xiao long bao!

Q. Tell us something about yourself that we might not know. Party tricks? Secret hobbies?

I’m a walking contradiction ‚Äì a shy extrovert, if you can believe it! In unfamiliar settings, I’m a silent observer, soaking in the atmosphere like a sponge. But put me with the right people, and there’s a whole other me waiting to unleash! Suddenly, I’m the life of the party, chatting away until the sun comes up (though at that point, my “active listening” skills might take a backseat).

Q. Lightning Round! 

‚ÄîMost-visited website: Shopping website (don’t judge!)


‚ÄîMust-have gadget: Phone


‚ÄîMost-read book: Product Led SEO


‚ÄîGo-to podcast: I’m still on the hunt for the perfect podcast

Find out more about Mina’s appearance at WordCamp Asia 2024 here.

title.rendered: Announcing Our Sixth Invited Speaker: Dr. JU-CHUN KO

content.rendered:
We are thrilled to unveil our sixth invited speaker for WordCamp Asia 2024, Dr. JU-CHUN (JC) KO, a distinguished figure whose contributions have continually shaped the digital and CMS community in Taipei and beyond.

About Dr. JU-CHUN KO

Dr. KO‚Äôs journey through the realms of technology and digital innovation is nothing short of inspiring. Currently serving as an At-Large Legislator and adjunct assistant professor at the Graduate Institute of Networking and Multimedia at National Taiwan University, he has been a pivotal presence in the CMS community since 2004, notably engaging in blog writing and organizing WordPress-related events.

After obtaining his Ph.D. in Computer Science from National Taiwan University in 2012, Dr. KO expanded his horizons to Keio University’s Graduate School of Media Design (KMD) in Japan for postdoctoral research, followed by an enriching experience at Singularity University in the US. His roles have been as diverse as they are impressive, including his service as the Taiwan AI/Web3 Growth Partner for the Dentsu Group in Japan and founding the acclaimed technology podcast “dAb in Tech.”

Dr. KO‚Äôs commitment to the WordPress community is evident from his active involvement in organizing and participating in events such as the Taipei WordPress Meetup in 2013 and a more intimate gathering in 2017. His invitation to speak at WordCamp Asia 2024 is a testament to his enduring impact and visionary outlook on the future of digital publishing and web technologies.

Session Details

Prepare to embark on a transformative journey with Dr. KO as he delves into the integration of Web3 technologies within the WordPress ecosystem. His session, “Web3 on WordPress: Unlocking New Frontiers,” promises to be an enlightening exploration of how decentralized technologies and the innovative “Writing as NFT” system developed by the LikeCoin organization are redefining content management and digital publishing.

Gain insights into the evolution from traditional blogging to the forefront of Web3 and decentralized publishing, uncovering the immense potential these advancements hold for content creators, digital entrepreneurs, and the broader WordPress community. This session is not just about understanding the technological shift but embracing the opportunities it presents for autonomy, content monetization, and the creation of a truly decentralized web.

Stay Tuned for more information

We will be delivering more information about our speaker lineup, session details, and full depth of the schedule. Keep an eye on our blog and social media channels for the latest updates on WordCamp Asia 2024.

title.rendered: Behind the Lineup: Miriam Schwab

content.rendered:
As we countdown to WordCamp Asia 2024, each week we‚Äôre inviting you to go behind the lineup and get to know the folks who will be taking to the stage. In today‚Äôs post, we chat with Miriam Schwab about the juggling act that is being a mom of seven‚Äîwhilst also founding, and selling, two WordPress businesses.

Q. Firstly, welcome to the lineup! We‚Äôre so glad to have you here. Can you start by telling us a bit about yourself? Where will you be joining the event from, and what does your day-to-day look like?

I’m joining the event from Israel. My day to day is quite busy as a mom. I get up early to do laundry, prepare lunches for the kids, drink my coffee (very important) and go on a morning walk. Then I start my day fresh and energized. The rest of the day flows as necessary, and can include welcome (and unwelcome) surprises, but I like that my days are dynamic. It keeps things interesting. At the end of the day me and the kids plan dinner, eat, maybe hangout and watch something together, and then it’s bed time.

Q. We‚Äôre lucky to be welcoming a diverse range of speakers to our program in 2024. What interested you to apply to WordCamp Asia as a speaker?

I love WordCamps and speaking at these conferences is such a privilege. I’m grateful I can share my knowledge and experiences and hope that it’s helpful to others.

Q. What can audiences expect to learn from your talk/s? Are there any advance sneak peeks or knowledge bombs you can offer us?

I’m going to talk about the juggling act that is being a mom of seven while founding, and selling, two WordPress businesses. It’s a unique perspective, and I think there will be some nuggets in there for everyone.

Q. What are you most looking forward to at WordCamp Asia 2024? Is there someone you‚Äôre looking forward to rubbing shoulder with, or a local delicacy you‚Äôd like to sample? 

I’m always excited to meet up with the WordPress community. It’s exciting, interactive and fun. I’m very much looking forward to seeing Taipei‚Äîthis is one place I never dreamed I’d get to visit, and it looks so beautiful! So I’m very excited to experience this new place.

Q. Tell us something about yourself that we might not know. Party tricks? Secret hobbies?

Between being a mom and business woman, I don’t have time or energy for hobbies. When I do have some downtime, I usually watch a TV show or movie. Not very exciting.

Q. Lightning Round! 

Most-visited website: Facebook.com. Kind of embarrassing, but true!

Most-have gadget: My cellphone standholder thingy. I have one and it’s great by my desk or in the kitchen.

Most-read book: The Lean Startup, by Eric Ries.

Go-to podcast: None. I like listening to episodes here and there, but podcasts put me to sleep! Not because the content isn’t interesting, but the sound of people talking does that to me. So I’m all about my Apple Music library.

Find out more about Miriam’s appearance at WordCamp Asia 2024 here.

title.rendered: Behind the Lineup: Shen Yi Ting

content.rendered:
As we countdown to WordCamp Asia 2024, each week we‚Äôre inviting you to go behind the lineup and get to know the folks who will be taking to the stage. In today‚Äôs post, we chat with YI-TING SHEN, a Taiwanese cyber-security expert about building your own security tools, and safe plugin development practice.

Q. Firstly, welcome to the lineup! We‚Äôre so glad to have you here. Can you start by telling us a bit about yourself? Where will you be joining the event from, and what does your day-to-day look like?

My name is YI-TING SHEN, but I am more accustomed to everyone calling me Noflag. I am Taiwanese. I am passionate about information security technology, and occasionally develop interesting projects. I have been working for an information security company for more than three years.

I also work as an Organizer in the Google Developer Groups (GDG) in Taichung, Taiwan, supporting Google’s technology exchange activities. I often think about what kind of projects to do and go to seminars to share this interesting content. As a GDG Organizer, I think this is the most interesting part.

Q. We‚Äôre lucky to be welcoming a diverse range of speakers to our program in 2024. What interested you to apply to WordCamp Asia as a speaker?

I saw the Taiwanese WordPress community promoting the event at seminars, and after communicating with them, I was determined to submit an application.

Q. What can audiences expect to learn from your talk/s? Are there any advance sneak peeks or knowledge bombs you can offer us?

We have developed an interesting white box detection tool. Our content is more oriented towards how you can create your own information security detection tools through the development process.

In my session, you can learn to build various security tools and work together to create a safer security environment for WordPress. At the same time, developers can also learn safer plugin development skills. I hope everyone will gain something.

Q. What are you most looking forward to at WordCamp Asia 2024? Is there someone you‚Äôre looking forward to rubbing shoulder with, or a local delicacy you‚Äôd like to sample? 

I hope to meet and communicate with many developers from different countries. As a Taiwanese, I am looking forward to taking everyone tasting Taiwanese food!

Q. Tell us something about yourself that we might not know. Party tricks? Secret hobbies?

I am a human being who hates Taiwan‚Äôs education system, so I joined a security company after graduating from high school. Also, I particularly like to assemble models, such as Lego models that you can assemble into a character or building.

Q. Lightning Round! 

Most-visited website: GPT, Gemini.

Most-have gadget: qFlipper.

Most-read book: Use python to fight against hackers for 300 rounds

Go-to podcast: 404 Not Found.

Find out more about YI-TING SHEN’s appearance at WordCamp Asia 2024¬†here.

title.rendered: Behind the Lineup: MinUk Kim

content.rendered:
As we countdown to WordCamp Asia 2024, each week we‚Äôre inviting you to go behind the lineup and get to know the folks who will be taking to the stage. In today‚Äôs post, we chat with MinUk Kim, a member of the TeamH4C hacking team based in Korea.

Q. Firstly, welcome to the lineup! We‚Äôre so glad to have you here. Can you start by telling us a bit about yourself? Where will you be joining the event from, and what does your day-to-day look like?

Hello! My name is Minwook Kim, and I am a white hacker in Korea. My nickname is me2nuk. My main field of study is web hacking, and I am interested in developing various vulnerability scanning tools as well as hacking.

Q. We‚Äôre lucky to be welcoming a diverse range of speakers to our program in 2024. What interested you to apply to WordCamp Asia as a speaker?

I saw a lot of developer mistakes in the WordPress plugins vulnerabilities that I discovered while creating vulnerability scanning tools. I want to tell developers how to prevent vulnerabilities if they pay a little more attention, so I applied as a speaker.

Q. What can audiences expect to learn from your talk/s? Are there any advance sneak peeks or knowledge bombs you can offer us?

You can see the prevention of vulnerabilities and what different developers are making mistakes. If it’s a knowledge bomb, I think the process of finding vulnerabilities will be a little complicated.

Q. What are you most looking forward to at WordCamp Asia 2024? Is there someone you‚Äôre looking forward to rubbing shoulder with, or a local delicacy you‚Äôd like to sample?¬†

I am not good at English, so I don’t know if I can go well with it. üòÖ I just hope that I can meet various people and return to Korea safely.

Q. Lightning Round!¬†

Most-visited website: Google.

Most-have gadget: Laptop and iPhone.

Most-read book: High Performance Python by Micha Gorelick and Ian Ozsvald

Go-to podcast: POCLANOS playlist

Find out more about MinUk Kim’s appearance at WordCamp Asia 2024¬†here.

title.rendered: Announcing Our Fifth Invited Speaker: Tim Ferriss

content.rendered:
Update [ March 4, 2024, 12pm (UTC+8) ]

Tim Ferriss is unable to speak at WordCamp Asia due to unforeseen circumstances. 

We are thrilled to announce that Tim Ferriss, a renowned author, entrepreneur, and podcast host, will be joining us as the fifth invited speaker at WordCamp Asia 2024. Tim brings a wealth of knowledge and experience, having been recognized as one of the most innovative business minds by Fast Company and named in Fortune‚Äôs ‚Äú40 under 40.‚Äù

About Tim Ferriss

As an early-stage technology investor and advisor, Tim has been instrumental in the success of companies like Uber, Facebook, Shopify, Duolingo, Alibaba, among over 50+ others. His keen eye for potential and strategic insight has propelled these businesses to the forefront of their respective industries.

Tim is perhaps best known for his groundbreaking work as an author, with five #1 New York Times and Wall Street Journal bestsellers to his name, including “The 4-Hour Workweek” and “Tools of Titans: The Tactics, Routines, and Habits of Billionaires, Icons, and World-Class Performers“. These books have not only transformed the way we think about work, productivity, and success but have also established Tim as a leading voice in self-improvement and business strategy.

Beyond his writing, Tim has also made a significant impact through “The Tim Ferriss Show” podcast. Dubbed “the Oprah of audio” by The Observer, his podcast was the first business/interview series to surpass 100 million downloads and has now exceeded 900 million. Through his in-depth interviews with billionaires, icons, and world-class performers, Tim has uncovered the routines, habits, and tactics that lead to excellence.

Session Details

At WordCamp Asia 2024, Tim Ferriss will share his insights in a session titled “Lessons Learned from 20 Years of Blogging and 10 Years of Podcasting.” This session promises to be an invaluable opportunity for attendees to learn from one of the most influential figures in the digital and entrepreneurial world. Whether you’re a blogger, podcaster, entrepreneur, or simply a fan of Tim’s work, this session is sure to inspire and enlighten.

Stay Tuned for more information

We will be delivering more information about our speaker lineup, session details, and full depth of the schedule. Keep an eye on our blog and social media channels for the latest updates on WordCamp Asia 2024. 

Get Your Tickets Now

content.rendered:

This year, the sessions have been organized into four distinct categories, each tailored to offer insights and knowledge in unique areas of WordPress and the tech industry. 

Whether you’re a developer, designer, marketer, or WordPress enthusiast, understanding these categories will help you tailor your experience to best suit your interests and professional needs. 

Let’s dive into what each category has to offer and highlight some of the sessions that you won’t want to miss. In this article, you will find out what our ‚ÄúBeyond‚Äù category offers..

Sessions of ‚ÄúGrowth‚Äù

Growth is a theme that runs through all sessions at WordCamp Asia 2024, emphasizing not just personal and professional development, but also the expansion and enrichment of teams and the community as a whole.

This category is for those who are looking to grow in every aspect of their WordPress journey.

title.rendered: Behind the Lineup: Ricky Blacker

content.rendered:
As we countdown to WordCamp Asia 2024, each week we‚Äôre inviting you to go behind the lineup and get to know the folks who will be taking to the stage. In today‚Äôs post, we chat with Ricky Blacker, a self taught web professional, co-organizer for the Brisbane and Sunshine Coast WordPress Meetup groups in Australia, and serial hobbyist.

Q. Firstly, welcome to the lineup! We‚Äôre so glad to have you here. Can you start by telling us a bit about yourself? Where will you be joining the event from, and what does your day-to-day look like?

I live in Brisbane Australia and work for WP Engine as a Senior Partner Enablement Manager. My main role is to help agencies and brands understand how to use our platform from a technology standpoint.

I am also a musician and play keyboards and guitar in a rock band called the TommyCatz. I am a serial hobbyist, my wife says I have way too many hobbies, and she is probably right.

Q. We‚Äôre lucky to be welcoming a diverse range of speakers to our program in 2024. What interested you to apply to WordCamp Asia as a speaker?

I am always excited to be involved with WordCamps across the globe, whether it is helping organise, volunteering or speaking, but this time I had an important message I needed to share with the WordPress community and being able to do that at WordCamp Asia would allow me to do that to a very large audience with the rest of the world eagerly looking on, so it made sense to apply.

Q. What can audiences expect to learn from your talk/s? Are there any advance sneak peeks or knowledge bombs you can offer us?

In my talk I hope to build awareness of how important it is to implement accessibility into every website, this not only helps those with disabilities to be able to access the content on the web, but it also has many benefits beyond this.

Q. What are you most looking forward to at WordCamp Asia 2024? Is there someone you‚Äôre looking forward to rubbing shoulder with, or a local delicacy you‚Äôd like to sample?¬†

I am totally looking forward to sampling some of the culinary delights from Taipei, especially want to try the Scallion and Daikon Pancake, also can’t wait to catch up with some of my WordPress friends that I only get to see at WordCamps as well as making some new friends along the way.

Q. Tell us something about yourself that we might not know. Party tricks? Secret hobbies?

I have soooo many hobbies, and I wish they were secret enough my wife did not find out as she says I have way too many, like flying remote control planes and drones, playing computer games, riding motorcycles, music recording and production, BBQing and smoking meats and just recently 3D printing

Q. Lightning Round!¬†

Most-visited website: Google Search, I am always looking up information on all sorts of things.

Most-have gadget: My Samsung Galaxy Watch.

Most-read book: The Hitchhikers Guide to the Galaxy, by Douglas Adams.

Go-to podcast: Believe it or not, I don’t listen to podcasts.

Find out more about Ricky’s appearance at WordCamp Asia 2024¬†here.

Imagine AI as your design helper, making Gutenberg and FSE more versatile. With Kubio, the block editor becomes a powerful site builder for creating awesome websites. Experience a simpler way to design with Kubio, as it brings AI to WordPress, opening up new possibilities for your creative journey.

title.rendered: Behind the Lineup: Nada ElSharkawy

content.rendered:
As we countdown to WordCamp Asia 2024, each week we‚Äôre inviting you to go behind the lineup and get to know the folks who will be taking to the stage. In today‚Äôs post, we chat with Nada ElSharkawy, the ¬†Senior Manager, Marketing for GoDaddy and an expert restaurant recommender.

Q. Firstly, welcome to the lineup! We‚Äôre so glad to have you here. Can you start by telling us a bit about yourself? Where will you be joining the event from, and what does your day-to-day look like?

I am a Senior Marketing Manager at GoDaddy and part of the Commercial Success Team. I’ll be joining the event from Dubai, which has been my home for the past 2 years. I’ve lived in 3 countries and speak three-and-a-half languages.

My day to day is very simple, as I work from home, I always have my morning coffee with 2 dates then prepare breakfast and check my emails, I head to the gym and train for around an hour, then head home roll my sleeves and start working! I have a few meetings during the day and work a lot with data‚Äîanalyzing and strategizing! I try to cook a healthy dinner and have some quality time with my husband at the end of the day, or go on a walk if the weather is nice.

Q. We‚Äôre lucky to be welcoming a diverse range of speakers to our program in 2024. What interested you to apply to WordCamp Asia as a speaker?

I’ve been speaking at events for the past 5 years, and when I attended WC Asia 2023 I listened to great talks but noticed that there were no Arab females present on stage. This year, I wanted to represent all the amazing Arab females in tech and in the WordPress world and share my experience and expertise with the WordPress community.

Q. What can audiences expect to learn from your talk/s? Are there any advance sneak peeks or knowledge bombs you can offer us?

I’ll be sharing my experience with meetups, but I’ve also been inspired by the community and will be sharing some of their highs and lows in my talk. I hope that my talk inspires more and more people to start and attend meetups around the world.

Q. What are you most looking forward to at WordCamp Asia 2024? Is there someone you‚Äôre looking forward to rubbing shoulder with, or a local delicacy you‚Äôd like to sample?¬†

I am looking forward to the night markets (and of course Boba tea!)

Q. Lightning Round!¬†

Most-visited website: WhatsApp Web

Most-have gadget: Apple Watch

Most-read book: 101 Essays That Will Change the Way You Think

Go-to podcast: Huberman Lab

Find out more about Nada’s appearance at WordCamp Asia 2024¬†here.

title.rendered: Behind the Lineup: Adam Silverstein

content.rendered:
As we countdown to WordCamp Asia 2024, each week we‚Äôre inviting you to go behind the lineup and get to know the folks who will be taking to the stage. In today‚Äôs post, we chat with Adam Silverstein, a WordPress core committer who loves rafting, playing mbira, and tending his oversized garden.

Q. Firstly, welcome to the lineup! We‚Äôre so glad to have you here. Can you start by telling us a bit about yourself? Where will you be joining the event from, and what does your day-to-day look like?

I’ll be traveling from Colorado, USA. I live in the mountains where this time of year is snowy and cold! Besides sitting at my desk, I like going on walks, cooking and playing Mbira (a traditional African thumb piano).

Q. We‚Äôre lucky to be welcoming a diverse range of speakers to our program in 2024. What interested you to apply to WordCamp Asia as a speaker?

I had a great experience at WordCamp Asia and really wanted to attend in 2024. Being a speaker helps motivate/justify the expense and time required to make it. Also, I’m super excited about sharing my talk on INP with the community.

Q. What can audiences expect to learn from your talk/s? Are there any advance sneak peeks or knowledge bombs you can offer us?

Attendees will get a deep dive into INP (Interaction to Next Paint) which will replace FID in the Core Web Vitals in March. Attendees will learn why INP is important and valuable for site owners and developers, what exactly it measures and how to debug and improve it.

Q. What are you most looking forward to at WordCamp Asia 2024? Is there someone you‚Äôre looking forward to rubbing shoulder with, or a local delicacy you‚Äôd like to sample? 

I’m extremely excited about visiting Taipei and connecting in person with my friends from the region in person.

Q. Tell us something about yourself that we might not know. Party tricks? Secret hobbies?

Outside of computer work I’ve been an Organic Farmer for most of my life, growing vegetables, fruits and flowers for my region. These days I mostly grow Winter Squash (and Hay).

Q. Lightning Round! 

Most-visited website: Asana.

Must-have gadget: Magnetic charger stand.

Most-read book: The Self Sufficient Gardener.

Go-to podcast: Wait, Wait, Don’t Tell Me.

Find out more about Adam’s appearance at WordCamp Asia 2024¬†here.

title.rendered: Behind the Lineup: Phoomparin Mano

content.rendered:
As we countdown to WordCamp Asia 2024, each week we‚Äôre inviting you to go behind the lineup and get to know the folks who will be taking to the stage. In today‚Äôs post, we chat with Phoomparin Mano, an indie hacker from Bangkok.

Q. Firstly, welcome to the lineup! We‚Äôre so glad to have you here. Can you start by telling us a bit about yourself? Where will you be joining the event from, and what does your day-to-day look like?

I’m Poom, a software engineer from Bangkok, Thailand. I like to work with cutting-edge web technologies and explore low-level tech such as WebAssembly, Zig and Rust, and I also organize 50+ events for creative technologists in Bangkok, such as the Bangkok Open Source Hackathon.

I’ve taken a break from work now, so mostly an indie hacker‚Äîtravelling around Bangkok to write code among nature, relax in onsen baths, and hosting events for my Thai folks.

Q. We‚Äôre lucky to be welcoming a diverse range of speakers to our program in 2024. What interested you to apply to WordCamp Asia as a speaker?

My senior Jabont introduced me to WordCamp‚ÄîI don’t usually use WordPress much, but the community seems really friendly and nice, so I want to meet the awesome folks working on the web.

Q. What can audiences expect to learn from your talk/s? Are there any advance sneak peeks or knowledge bombs you can offer us?

I’ll share how web technologies such as Astro, Svelte and Nuxt can make your life a lot easier, and how modern JavaScript doesn’t have to be overwhelming. Expect to see how you can integrate WordPress with highly-interactive and customized applications e.g. 3D websites!

Q. What are you most looking forward to at WordCamp Asia 2024? Is there someone you‚Äôre looking forward to rubbing shoulder with, or a local delicacy you‚Äôd like to sample? 

I look forward to meeting the people there! This will be my first time in the WordPress community.

Q. Tell us something about yourself that we might not know. Party tricks? Secret hobbies?

I like onsen baths, macarons, medium-rare steaks and being in the wilderness, and swimming in seas and waterfalls! I watched 1080 episodes of One Piece in 3 months‚Äîspent around 480 hours straight binging the show.

Q. Lightning Round! 

Most-visited website: YouTube and BiliBili – I’m addicted to anime at the moment.

Must-have gadget: Kindle – great for curing my phone addiction!

Most-read book: Alchemy by Rory Sutherland.

Go-to podcast: Starstuff by Spaceth.co.

title.rendered: Thanks to Snow Mountain Sponsor ‚Äì Google

content.rendered:
We’re thrilled to announce Google as a prestigious Snow Mountain sponsor for WordCamp Asia 2024. This partnership is destined to enrich the WordCamp experience, setting the stage for an event that transcends traditional boundaries.

Google’s mission to organize the world’s information and make it universally accessible aligns perfectly with WordPress’s ethos to democratize the web. This synergy is set to make WordCamp Asia 2024 a standout event featuring world-class speakers, innovative workshops, and unique networking opportunities.

Jointly, we highlight both the collective efforts of the worldwide WordPress community and Google’s unwavering commitment to enhancing the digital landscape. By facilitating equal access to the infinite opportunities in the online world, we make tangible strides towards digital democratization.

Let’s express our heartfelt appreciation for Google’s pivotal role in shaping WordCamp Asia 2024. We eagerly await unveiling the remarkable manifestation of this partnership next year at the Taipei International Convention Center (TICC), Taiwan, in March. Join us for a spectacular event powered by WordPress and Google.

  • At Google, we believe that WordPress is one of the key enablers of an open, thriving, and rich web ecosystem. Our goal is to help everyone succeed on the web by improving the performance, security, and capabilities of millions of WordPress-powered sites. Through partnerships with developers, core contributors, and site owners, as well as WordPress plugins and technologies for the wider web, we aim to optimize performance and speed in every aspect of WordPress.

title.rendered: Behind the Lineup: Aaron D. Campbell

content.rendered:
As we countdown to WordCamp Asia 2024, each week we‚Äôre inviting you to go behind the lineup and get to know the folks who will be taking to the stage. In today‚Äôs post, we chat with Aaron D. Campbell, Director of Product at A2 Hosting about his experiences with WordCamp Asia, his party trick, and his love of high performance UTVs.

Q. Firstly, welcome to the lineup! We‚Äôre so glad to have you here. Can you start by telling us a bit about yourself? Where will you be joining the event from, and what does your day-to-day look like?

I live in Seminole, Oklahoma, a small town of ~7000 people that I often say is “the middle of nowhere in the middle of the United States”, although we’re actually about 540km from the true middle. My day to day as Director of Product at A2 Hosting consists mostly of setting the direction and vision for our products, enabling my team to create amazing product plans, and shepherding those through the process from vision to reality. Personally, my day to day varies a lot with the weather. Right now while it’s cold, I catch up on my reading and enjoy the peace that comes from staying inside. When the weather is beautiful, I try to get out as often as I can – maybe for a walk, but especially to the local off-road track when I can. When it’s incredibly hot, I spend every second I can inside a pool (missing that hot weather at the moment!).

Q. We‚Äôre lucky to be welcoming a diverse range of speakers to our program in 2024. What interested you to apply to WordCamp Asia as a speaker?

The first WordCamp Asia was an absolute delight, and I knew immediately that I wanted to return. People that shared their experiences, learnings, struggles, and epiphanies with me along my path through life, and specifically in my career, helped me get to where I am today. Any chance I have to share my own experiences back to help others, is almost like me making a payment on that debt.

Q. What can audiences expect to learn from your talk/s? Are there any advance sneak peeks or knowledge bombs you can offer us?

Your reputation is absolutely key to achieving your goals. It’s more than your portfolio or your resume, it can be built both in and out of work, and it’s always yours no matter where you move to or who you work for. It’s worth taking the time to start building it purposefully so you can use it effectively.

Q. What are you most looking forward to at WordCamp Asia 2024? Is there someone you‚Äôre looking forward to rubbing shoulder with, or a local delicacy you‚Äôd like to sample? 

My brother-in-law told me that I absolutely have to eat at the top of the Taipei 101 building, so I think that’s tops on my list right now. In general, I love experiencing new places through food…so I’m ABSOLUTELY open to any and all recommendations!

Q. Tell us something about yourself that we might not know. Party tricks? Secret hobbies?

As an introvert, I think my biggest party trick is surviving the party. My not-so-secret, but probably less known, hobby is going fast in or on anything with a motor. In the past I have been heavily into motorcycles, especially of the off-road variety, and now I find myself mostly enjoying high performance UTVs. It’s something I do with my son, who’s now 20, and we get quite competitive!

Q. Lightning Round!¬†

Most-visited website: google – I’m an information addict and it’s still my primary portal to finding that info!

Must-have gadget: My phone – I use it for everything

Most-read book: I prefer fiction – especially fantasy. If you’ve never read the Eragon series you should. It’s creative, well paced, and generally fun – avoid the movie at all costs.

Go-to podcast: The WP Briefing is the only podcast that I never miss an episode of – https://wordpress.org/news/podcast/

Find out more about Aaron’s appearance at WordCamp Asia 2024 here.

title.rendered: Announcing Our Fourth Invited Speaker: Josepha Haden Chomphosy

content.rendered:
We are excited to introduce our fourth invited speaker, Josepha Haden Chomphosy, for WordCamp Asia 2024. Just like our previously announced  speakers, we are excited to share the remarkable journey and insights that Josepha will bring to our event.

About Josepha Haden Chomphosy

Josepha Haden Chomphosy currently holds the esteemed position of Executive Director of the WordPress project, which stands as one of the most widely used content management systems globally. With a background steeped in communications and digital media, Josepha brings a distinctive perspective to the realm of technology. Her passion lies in nurturing inclusive communities and empowering individuals with the skills needed to thrive in the digital age.

Since joining the project in 2019 as Executive Director, Josepha has focused on building a more diverse and inclusive community, expanding the reach of the platform, and empowering users to create amazing digital experiences.

Recognized for her exceptional leadership abilities, fervor for open source software, and unwavering commitment to fostering a fair and inclusive tech industry, Josepha is sought after as both a speaker and mentor. She has garnered accolades for her contributions not only to the technology sector but also to the broader world.

For more insights, you can explore her occasional writings on josepha.blog.

Session Details

In the session Josepha will explore the future of open source, emphasizing the importance of nurturing what grounds us, effectively managing distractions, and cultivating new opportunities.

As the Executive Director of WordPress, Josepha brings a wealth of experience and a unique perspective to the discussion. Discover how one of the world’s largest open-source Content Management Systems is evolving and breaking down barriers to create thriving community spaces. Join us for an illuminating journey into the world of open source and the transformation of walled gardens into dynamic hubs of collaboration and innovation!

Stay Tuned for more information

We will be delivering more information about our speaker lineup, session details, and full depth of the schedule. Keep an eye on our blog and social media channels for the latest updates on WordCamp Asia 2024.

title.rendered: Behind the Lineup: Pascal Birchler

content.rendered:
As we countdown to WordCamp Asia 2024, each week we‚Äôre inviting you to go behind the lineup and get to know the folks who will be taking to the stage. In today‚Äôs post, we chat with Pascal Birchler from Google and a long-time WordPress contributor.

Q. Firstly, welcome to the lineup! We‚Äôre so glad to have you here. Can you start by telling us a bit about yourself? Where will you be joining the event from, and what does your day-to-day look like?

I am a long-time WordPress community member and contributor based in Zurich, Switzerland. Over the years I have done a lot of things around WordPress, be it organizing and speaking at events, developing popular plugins, or building new features in core itself. Today, I am part of a team at Google that is passionate about making the web and especially CMSes like WordPress faster. So my day-to-day involves mostly contributions to the core performance team. This goes from analyzing latest trends to identifying and fixing bugs to writing tools and documentation for developers so they are well-equipped for building performant solutions.

Q. We‚Äôre lucky to be welcoming a diverse range of speakers to our program in 2024. What interested you to apply to WordCamp Asia as a speaker?

I have fond memories of the few times I have been to events in the APAC region, for example WordCamp Tokyo, which was a blast. People are super friendly and eager to learn about all things WordPress. Originally I wanted to attend already in 2023 (and in 2020 before it was cancelled) but couldn’t make it. So this time I am extra excited to attend. And because there’s so many exciting things going on in WordPress that I want to share with people, I figured WordCamp Asia was the best opportunity to do so.

Q. What can audiences expect to learn from your talk/s? Are there any advance sneak peeks or knowledge bombs you can offer us?

In my talk I will share the latest and greatest around performance in WordPress and what it means to try to make good performance accessible for everyone. Things are moving fast, so I hope to be able to share some cool demos and facts about upcoming developments in this space.

Q. What are you most looking forward to at WordCamp Asia 2024? Is there someone you‚Äôre looking forward to rubbing shoulder with, or a local delicacy you‚Äôd like to sample? 

I’m generally eager to meet old and new friends alike and get to know a new city and culture. Haven’t done any planning so far but I’m open to suggestions!

Q. Tell us something about yourself that we might not know. Party tricks? Secret hobbies?

Tough one! No party tricks I’m afraid. A recent new hobby is running. I suppose I took my interest in performance “offline” as I started running more regularly and even finished my first half marathon in 2023!

Q. Lightning Round!¬†

Website: probably github.com, followed by google.com

Gadget: my phone

Book: I usually only read them once, so none in particular

Podcast: a few ones about Swiss football (soccer)

Find out more about Pascal’s appearance at WordCamp Asia 2024 here.
